paragraphs.text:
%md
Text Classification is a basic Natural Lauguage Processing (NLP) task which assigns tags or categories to text according to its content. Text Classification can be used for sentiment analysis, spam detection, topic labeling, etc.

In this notebook, we will use Analytics Zoo built-in TextClassifier model and TextSet API to classify news categories.

msg.data:
Text Classification is a basic Natural Lauguage Processing (NLP) task which assigns tags or categories to text according to its content. Text Classification can be used for sentiment analysis, spam detection, topic labeling, etc.

In this notebook, we will use Analytics Zoo built-in TextClassifier model and TextSet API to classify news categories.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We first download and extract the [20news](http://qwone.com/~jason/20Newsgroups/) dataset.

We also download the pre-trained [GloVe](https://nlp.stanford.edu/projects/glove/) word embeddings. Here we choose 'glove.6B.200d.txt', you can also choose other embedding files as well.

msg.data:
We first download and extract the 20news dataset.

We also download the pre-trained GloVe word embeddings. Here we choose ‘glove.6B.200d.txt’, you can also choose other embedding files as well.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from qcloud_cos import CosConfig
from qcloud_cos import CosS3Client
import sys

secret_id = 'AKIDy0ra5NkDUYNwLWqfRxxkKvFBUxF33Tc4'      # 替换为用户的 secretId
secret_key = 'mDQgtyuaz9tLn21kDWcWGwPfiDakmZ5R'      # 替换为用户的 secretKey
region = 'ap-shanghai'     # 替换为用户的 Region
token = None                # 使用临时密钥需要传入 Token，默认为空，可不填
scheme = 'https'            # 指定使用 http/https 协议来访问 COS，默认为 https，可不填
config = CosConfig(Region=region, SecretId=secret_id, SecretKey=secret_key, Token=token, Scheme=scheme)
# 2. 获取客户端对象
client = CosS3Client(config)

%pyspark
response = client.get_object(
    Bucket='demo-sh-1258997244',
    Key='/20news-18828.tar.gz'
)
print(type(response['Body']))
response['Body'].get_stream_to_file('/tmp/20news-18828.tar.gz')

%pyspark
import tarfile
tar = tarfile.open("/tmp/20news-18828.tar.gz", "r:gz")
tar.extractall("/tmp")
tar.close()

%pyspark
response = client.get_object(
    Bucket='demo-sh-1258997244',
    Key='/glove.6B/glove.6B.200d.txt'
)
response['Body'].get_stream_to_file('/tmp/glove.6B.200d.txt')

%md
## Initialization
Import necessary libraries and initialize the SparkContext.

msg.data:
Initialization

Import necessary libraries and initialize the SparkContext.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
import datetime as dt

from bigdl.optim.optimizer import Adagrad
from zoo.common.nncontext import init_nncontext
from zoo.feature.text import TextSet
from zoo.models.textclassification import TextClassifier

sc = init_nncontext("Text Classification Example")

%md
## Data Preparation and Preprocessing

We first take a look at the unzipped 20news dataset.

msg.data:
Data Preparation and Preprocessing

We first take a look at the unzipped 20news dataset.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
os.listdir("/tmp/20news-18828")

%md
Read the texts of each news category as a TextSet.

msg.data: Read the texts of each news category as a TextSet.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
text_set = TextSet.read(path="/tmp/20news-18828").to_distributed(sc)

%md
You can easily call transformation methods of a TextSet one by one to build the text transformation pipeline and do text preprocessing in a distributed fashion.

msg.data: You can easily call transformation methods of a TextSet one by one to build the text transformation pipeline and do text preprocessing in a distributed fashion.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
transformed = text_set.tokenize().normalize()\
        .word2idx(remove_topN=10, max_words_num=5000)\
        .shape_sequence(len=500).generate_sample()
word_index = transformed.get_word_index()

%md
We split the preprocessed TextSet into training and validation set.

msg.data: We split the preprocessed TextSet into training and validation set.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
train_set, val_set = transformed.random_split([0.8, 0.2])

%md
## Model Definition and Training

We use built-in TextClassifier model in Analytics Zoo with CNN as encoder. You can try to use LSTM and GRU as well.

msg.data:
Model Definition and Training

We use built-in TextClassifier model in Analytics Zoo with CNN as encoder. You can try to use LSTM and GRU as well.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
model = TextClassifier(20, '/tmp/glove.6B.200d.txt', word_index, 500, encoder="cnn", encoder_output_dim=256)

msg.data:
creating: createZooKerasWordEmbedding
creating: createZooKerasSequential
creating: createZooKerasConvolution1D
creating: createZooKerasGlobalMaxPooling1D
creating: createZooKerasDense
creating: createZooKerasDropout
creating: createZooKerasActivation
creating: createZooKerasDense
creating: createZooTextClassifier

paragraphs.text:
%md
After creating the model, we use Keras-Style API to train the model in a distributed fashion.

The training may take several minutes.

msg.data:
After creating the model, we use Keras-Style API to train the model in a distributed fashion.

The training may take several minutes.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
model.compile(optimizer=Adagrad(learningrate=0.01, learningrate_decay=0.001),
              loss="sparse_categorical_crossentropy",
              metrics=['accuracy'])
app_name = 'textclassification-' + dt.datetime.now().strftime("%Y%m%d-%H%M%S")
model.set_tensorboard('/tmp/analytics_zoo_logs', app_name)
model.fit(train_set, batch_size=128, nb_epoch=5, validation_data=val_set)

%md
## Model Evaluation and Inference

We use the validation dataset to evaluate the trained model. You can observe around 85% accuracy after 20 epochs of training.

msg.data:
Model Evaluation and Inference

We use the validation dataset to evaluate the trained model. You can observe around 85% accuracy after 20 epochs of training.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
results = model.evaluate(val_set, batch_size=128)
for result in results:
    print(result)

msg.data:
Evaluated result: 0.5921568870544434, total_num: 121, method: Loss
Evaluated result: 0.8191207647323608, total_num: 3776, method: Top1Accuracy

paragraphs.text:
%md
Finally print out some prediction results to have a look.

msg.data: Finally print out some prediction results to have a look.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
predict_set = model.predict(val_set)
predicts = predict_set.get_predicts().take(3)
for predict in predicts:
    print(predict)

%md
In conclusion, this notebook guides you through the steps to build a text classification model using Analytics Zoo. The whole process should be straightforward and the code is neat.

Besides text classification, many more advanced NLP models are supported in Analytics Zoo, including text matching, sequence to sequence, transformer and BERT. If you are interested in these, feel free to find the corresponding documentations on our website: https://analytics-zoo.github.io/

msg.data:
In conclusion, this notebook guides you through the steps to build a text classification model using Analytics Zoo. The whole process should be straightforward and the code is neat.

Besides text classification, many more advanced NLP models are supported in Analytics Zoo, including text matching, sequence to sequence, transformer and BERT. If you are interested in these, feel free to find the corresponding documentations on our website: https://analytics-zoo.github.io/
